item.title: Notes on the Binomial distribution
item.description: Binomial distribution describes the number of successes in a series of \(n\) independent identical experiments: \(X=k\) if exactly \(k\) experiments out of \(n\) were successfull, while others were not. Parameters: \(n\) – number of experiments, \(p\) – probability of a success in a single experiment. Values: \(\{0,1,2,\ldots,n\}.\) Probability mass function: \[ P(X=k)={n\choose k}p^k(1-p)^{n-k}, \ k=0,1,2,\ldots,n. \] Derivation Let \(\xi_k,\) \(k=1,2,\ldots,n,\) be the result of \(k\)-th experiment, i.e. \(\xi_k=1\) if \(k\)-th experiment was successfull, and \(\xi_k=0\) otherwise.
